conclusion: Visitors can reach the observation deck in about one minute by taking the observation elevator. The elevator is simplified to only be affected by gravity and the tension of the rope. The elevator starts to ascend from rest at t=0, and the relationship between time and acceleration is shown in the diagram.

The acceleration-time graph shows the following segments: (1) From t=0 to t=1 second, acceleration is 2 m/s². (2) From t=1 to t=4 seconds, acceleration is 2 m/s². (3) From t=4 to t=5 seconds, acceleration is 2 m/s². (4) From t=5 to t=55 seconds, acceleration is -2 m/s². (5) From t=55 to t=56 seconds, acceleration is -2 m/s². (6) From t=56 to t=59 seconds, acceleration is -2 m/s². (7) From t=59 to t=60 seconds, acceleration is -2 m/s².
The velocity at any time t is the integral of the acceleration with respect to time: v(t) = ∫a(t) dt.

premise: From t=0 to t=1 second, acceleration is 2 m/s².
conclusion: The velocity from t=0 to t=1 second is v(1) = ∫₀¹ 2 dt = 2t|₀¹ = 2 × 1 - 2 × 0 = 2 m/s.

premise: From t=1 to t=4 seconds, acceleration is 2 m/s².
conclusion: The velocity from t=1 to t=4 seconds is v(4) = ∫₁⁴ 2 dt = 2t|₁⁴ = 2 × 4 - 2 × 1 = 8 - 2 = 6 m/s.

premise: From t=4 to t=5 seconds, acceleration is 2 m/s².
conclusion: The velocity from t=4 to t=5 seconds is v(5) = ∫₄⁵ 2 dt = 2t|₄⁵ = 2 × 5 - 2 × 4 = 10 - 8 = 2 m/s.

premise: From t=5 to t=55 seconds, acceleration is -2 m/s².
conclusion: The velocity from t=5 to t=55 seconds is v(55) = ∫₅⁵⁵ (-2) dt = -2t|₅⁵⁵ = -2 × 55 - (-2 × 5) = -110 + 10 = -100 m/s.

premise: From t=55 to t=56 seconds, acceleration is -2 m/s².
conclusion: The velocity from t=55 to t=56 seconds is v(56) = ∫₅₅⁵⁶ (-2) dt = -2t|₅₅⁵⁶ = -2 × 56 - (-2 × 55) = -112 + 110 = -2 m/s.
